snippet: While Senate leaders praised the progress that was made on a deal to reopen the government and raise the debt limit, it was clear that the most conservative members of the House were not going to go along quietly.
abstract: Senate leaders near completion of bipartisan deal to raise debt ceiling through Feb 7, 2014, and end government shutdown, but most House conservatives make it clear they will not go along quietly with plan; world braces for possibility of American default that could set off global financial disaster.

byline.original: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JEREMY W. PETERS
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Ashley Parker and Jonathan Weisman from Washington, Annie Lowrey from Boston and Nathaniel Popper from New York.

lead_paragraph: While Senate leaders praised the progress that was made on a deal to reopen the government and raise the debt limit, it was clear that the most conservative members of the House were not going to go along quietly.

headline.main: Senators Near Fiscal Deal, but the House Is Uncertain
headline.print_headline: Senate Leaders Near Fiscal Deal; House Uncertain
